data.title: Minnesota Timberwolves: Andrei Kirilenko assumes pivotal role with Kevin Love out
data.meta_description: The Timberwolves coaching staff has told Andrei Kirilenko it wants him to be the same versatile player he was during his first 10 NBA seasons with the Utah Jazz. That is, a player who defended opponents all over the court, found the open man and filled his stat line with rebounds, steals and blocked shots.Kirilenko […]
data.text:
To place an obituary, please include the information from the obituary checklist below in an email to obits@pioneerpress.com. There is no option to place them through our website. Feel free to contact our obituary desk at 651-228-5263 with any questions.

General Information:

Your full name,

Address (City, State, Zip Code),

Phone number,

And an alternate phone number (if any)

Obituary Specification:

Name of Deceased,

Obituary Text,

A photo in a JPEG or PDF file is preferable, TIF and other files are accepted, we will contact you if there are any issues with the photo.

Ad Run dates

There is a discount for running more than one day, but this must be scheduled on the first run date to apply.

If a photo is used, it must be used for both days for the discount to apply, contact us for more information.

Policies:

Verification of Death:

In order to publish obituaries a name and phone number of funeral home/cremation society is required. We must contact the funeral home/cremation society handling the arrangements during their business hours to verify the death. If the body of the deceased has been donated to the University of Minnesota Anatomy Bequest Program, or a similar program, their phone number is required for verification.

Please allow enough time to contact them especially during their limited weekend hours.

A death certificate is also acceptable for this purpose but only one of these two options are necessary.

Guestbook and Outside Websites:

We are not allowed to reference other media sources with a guestbook or an obituary placed elsewhere when placing an obituary in print and online. We may place a website for a funeral home or a family email for contact instead; contact us with any questions regarding this matter.

Obituary Process:

Once your submission is completed, we will fax or email a proof for review prior to publication in the newspaper. This proof includes price and days the notice is scheduled to appear.

Please review the proof carefully. We must be notified of errors or changes before the notice appears in the Pioneer Press based on each day’s deadlines.

After publication, we will not be responsible for errors that may occur after final proofing.

Online:

All obituaries appear on TwinCities.com with a permanent online guestbook presence. If you wish to have the online presence removed, you can contact us to remove the guestbook online. Changes to an online obituary can be handled through the obituary desk. Call us with further questions.

Payment Procedure:

Pre-payment is required for all obituary notices prior to publication by the deadline specified below in our deadline schedule. Please call 651-228-5263 with your payment information after you have received the proof and approved its contents.

Credit Card: Payment accepted by phone only due to PCI (Payment Card Industry) regulations

EFT: Check by phone. Please provide your routing number and account number.

Cash: Accepted at our FRONT COUNTER Monday – Friday from 8:00AM – 3:30PM

Rates:

The minimum charge is $162 for the first 10 lines.

Every line after the first 10 is $12.20.

If the ad is under 10 lines it will be charged the minimum rate of $162.

On a second run date, the lines are $8.20 per line, starting w/ the first line.

For example: if first run date was 20 lines the cost would be $164.

Each photo published is $125 per day.

For example: 2 photos in the paper on 2 days would be 4 photo charges at $500.

Deadlines:

Please follow deadline times to ensure your obituary is published on the day requested.

Hours

Deadline (no exceptions)

Ad

Photos

MEMORIAM (NON-OBITUARY) REQUEST

Unlike an obituary, Memoriam submissions are remembrances of a loved one who has passed. The rates for a memoriam differ from obituaries.

Please call or email us for more memoriam information

Please call 651-228-5280 for more information.

HOURS: Monday – Friday 8:00AM – 5:00PM (CLOSED WEEKENDS and HOLIDAYS)

Please submit your memoriam ad to memoriams@pioneerpress.com or call 651-228-5280.

The Timberwolves coaching staff has told Andrei Kirilenko it wants him to be the same versatile player he was during his first 10 NBA seasons with the Utah Jazz. That is, a player who defended opponents all over the court, found the open man and filled his stat line with rebounds, steals and blocked shots.

Kirilenko agrees with that plan. At 31, he is not interested in a makeover to help him replace two-time all-star forward Kevin Love for the next six to eight weeks.

A natural small forward, Kirilenko will shift to Love’s power forward spot while Love recovers from a broken right hand, but the Russian standout will not try to match the 26.0 points and 13.3 rebounds Love averaged last season.

“I’m not chasing stats,” Kirilenko said after practice Tuesday, Oct. 23. “I’m chasing good plays, things that can get us something. I’m not a guy who looks at stats. Whatever helps us win the games, I will do that.”

Until Love returns to the lineup in mid-December, the Wolves will have a very different look at power forward.

On defense, the 6-foot-9 Kirilenko could find himself defending a shooting guard or a power forward — unlike Love, who rarely was used in situations in which he had to defend someone other than a center or power forward.

On offense, where Love was known for putting up double-doubles in points and rebounds, Kirilenko is expected to help the Wolves develop a more balanced attack.

“He’s a better passer than the other big guys we have, and that’s going to help us,” coach Rick Adelman said. “He’s going to have the ball in his hands with some of the things we’re trying to do, but we’re still going to run the same plays.”

Kirilenko played small forward for most of his time with Utah, but Adelman preferred moving him to power forward rather than Derrick Williams. Williams will start at small forward in Wednesday night’s exhibition game against the Detroit Pistons in Winnipeg, Manitoba.

The Wolves are counting on the versatility in Kirilenko’s game to help them get through a difficult transition without Love and point guard Ricky Rubio (knee), who is not projected to play until mid-December at the earliest.

Few players can match Love’s production. In a survey released Tuesday on NBA.com, the league’s 30 general managers voted him the NBA’s best power forward.

Kirilenko understands the magnitude of his responsibility, but he shares Adelman’s belief that the entire team has a role in compensating for Love’s absence.

“It’s a tough time for us, and we’re learning, but there’s a lot of room for creativity,” Kirilenko said. “I see every guy on our team being able to make baskets. We just need to stay sharp as a team.”

A team effort might be required on the boards. The Wolves never had to worry about rebounding with Love on the floor. Kirilenko said he hopes to raise his rebounding average to at least eight per game.

The Wolves are hoping Williams, backup forwards Dante Cunningham and Lou Amundson, and centers Nikola Pekovic and Greg Stiemsma can ease the burden on Kirilenko under the basket and allow him to make plays.

“If Andrei pulls down a rebound, I’m taking off because he passes so well,” point guard J.J. Barea said. “It makes our job a little easier with him being able to get the ball up the floor.”

Kirilenko speaks fluent English but said he will pick his spots when it comes to assuming Love’s leadership role. Since Love’s injury, Kirilenko said he has been working on becoming more vocal in practice.

“Maybe I need to make everybody learn a little Russian,” he said, smiling. “I get confused sometimes on the court trying to talk to guys. I don’t really like telling guys what to do. We have grown men on the team. They already know what to do, but some things on the floor you definitely have to talk about.”

Follow Ray Richardson at twitter.com/twolvesnow.

Originally Published: October 22, 2012 at 11:01 p.m.
